# **INTRODUCTION**

The purpose of these analyses are to more fully explore the parent-pair offspring trio/triad data (i.e. cross data) for Gilmour Creek 2014-2016 in terms of spatiotemporal patterning and generate preliminary estimates of narrow-sense heritability using regression slope analysis. **NOTE: The bulk of 2016 origin data for Gilmour is missing as a result of the otolith shipping issue.**

## Offspring, dam, and sire relationships - dyads and triads

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
# dyad relationships - one row per offspring
gilmour_parents_paired_14_16 <- read_csv("../Gilmour/gilmour_parents_paired_14_16.csv") %>% 
     mutate(origin.par = factor(x = origin.par, levels = c("Natural", "Hatchery")))

# Read in paired data
gilmour_postQA_OceanAK_paired_14_16 <- read_csv("../Franz/Gilmour_14_16_postQA_OceanAK_paired_2014_2016_GILMOUR.csv")

OceanAK_paired <- function(indata_OceanAK_paired = gilmour_postQA_OceanAK_paired_14_16) {
   indata_OceanAK_paired %>% 
   select(franz_id, starts_with("Sample"), SILLY, `Fish ID`, starts_with("DNA"), SEX, `Length Mm`, `Otolith Mark Present`, `Otolith Mark ID`) %>% 
   rename(sample_id = "Sample ID", 
          Year = "Sample Year", 
          silly = "SILLY", 
          fish_id = "Fish ID", 
          dna_tray = "DNA Tray Code", 
          dna_well = "DNA Tray Well Code",
          Sex = "SEX",
          Length = "Length Mm") %>% 
   mutate(Origin = case_when(`Otolith Mark Present` == "YES" ~ "Hatchery",
                             `Otolith Mark Present` == "NO" ~ "Natural")) %>% 
   mutate(Origin = factor(x = Origin, levels = c("Natural", "Hatchery")))
}         

gilmour_OceanAK_paired_14_16 <- OceanAK_paired()

# Get offspring, dam, sire relationships and join
ods_relationships <- function(indata_ods = gilmour_parents_paired_14_16) {
  offspring_sire <- indata_ods %>% 
    filter(SEX.par == "M") %>% 
    select(Offspring, Parent_ID)

  offspring_dam <- indata_ods %>% 
    filter(SEX.par == "F") %>% 
    select(Offspring, Parent_ID)

  offspring_dam_sire <- offspring_dam %>% 
    full_join(offspring_sire, by = "Offspring", suffix = c(".dam", ".sire"))
}

gilmour_offspring_dam_sire_14_16 <- ods_relationships()

# Join back paired data to offspring, dam, and sire
(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_dam_sire <- gilmour_offspring_dam_sire_14_16 %>% 
  left_join(gilmour_OceanAK_paired_14_16, by = c("Offspring" = "franz_id")) %>% 
  left_join(gilmour_OceanAK_paired_14_16, by = c("Parent_ID.dam" = "franz_id"), suffix = c(".off", "")) %>% 
  left_join(gilmour_OceanAK_paired_14_16, by = c("Parent_ID.sire" = "franz_id"), suffix = c(".dam", ".sire")) %>% 
  mutate(date.off = dmy(`Sample Date.off`),
         date.dam = dmy(`Sample Date.dam`),
         date.sire = dmy(`Sample Date.sire`)) %>% 
  mutate(DOY.off = yday(date.off),
         DOY.dam = yday(date.dam),
         DOY.sire = yday(date.sire)))
```

## Triads - used for remaining analyses

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
triads <- function(indata_triads = gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_dam_sire) {
  indata_triads %>% 
  filter(!is.na(Parent_ID.dam) & !is.na(Parent_ID.sire)) 
}

(gilmour_triads_14_16 <- triads())
```

# **HERITABILITY**

For traits associated with fitness in natural populations, heritability is typically 0.1â€“0.2 (Wray and Visscher 2008 [https://www.nature.com/scitable/topicpage/estimating-trait-heritability-46889/] per Visscher et al. 2008). 

## Body Length

```{r}
# mid-parent trait values and cross info
triads_length <- function(indata_triads_length = gilmour_triads_14_16) {
  indata_triads_length %>%
  mutate(Length.par = (Length.dam + Length.sire) / 2) %>% 
  mutate(Cross = case_when(Origin.dam == "Natural" & Origin.sire == "Natural" ~ "NN",
                           Origin.dam == "Natural" & Origin.sire == "Hatchery" ~ "NH",
                           Origin.dam == "Hatchery" & Origin.sire == "Natural" ~ "HN",
                           Origin.dam == "Hatchery" & Origin.sire == "Hatchery" ~ "HH"))
}

gilmour_triads_length_14_16 <- triads_length()
```

### Scatterplots

```{r}
parents_paired_length_graph <- function(indata_parents_paired_length_graph = gilmour_parents_paired_14_16, title = "Gilmour_14_16\n\nRegression of Body Length by Sex") {
  indata_parents_paired_length_graph %>% 
  rename(length.par = "Length Mm.par", 
         length.off = "Length Mm.off") %>% 
  mutate(sex.par = case_when(SEX.par == "F" ~ "Parent: Female",
                             SEX.par == "M" ~ "Parent: Male")) %>% 
  mutate(sex.off = case_when(SEX.off == "F" ~ "Offspring: Female",
                             SEX.off == "M" ~ "Offspring: Male")) %>% 
  group_by(sex.par, sex.off) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = length.par, y = length.off, colour = origin.par)) +
  geom_abline(slope = 1) +
  geom_jitter(alpha = 0.2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  facet_grid(sex.off ~ sex.par) +
  labs(title = title,  colour = "Parent: Origin") +
  xlab("Parent Length (mm)") +
  ylab("Offspring Length (mm)") +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(text = element_text(size = 20))
}

parents_paired_length_graph()

h2_length_graph <- function(indata_h2_length_graph = gilmour_triads_length_14_16, title = "Gilmour_14_16\n\nRegression of Body Length by Cross") {
  indata_h2_length_graph %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Length.par, y = Length.off, colour = Cross)) +
  geom_abline(slope = 1) +

  labs(title = title, colour = "Parent: Origin") +

  theme(text = element_text(size = 20))
}

h2_length_graph()
```

### Correlation

We estimate narrow-sense heritability here, as well as for location and sample date, from r = âˆš(Â½)h^2.

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
parents_paired_length <- function(indata_triads_length = gilmour_triads_length_14_16) {
  indata_triads_length %>% 
  drop_na(Length.par, Length.off) %>% 
  mutate(sex.dam = case_when(Sex.dam == "F" ~ "Female")) %>%
  mutate(sex.sire = case_when(Sex.sire == "M" ~ "Male")) %>%
  mutate(sex.off = case_when(Sex.off == "F" ~ "Female",
                             Sex.off == "M" ~ "Male")) 
}

(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1 <- parents_paired_length() %>% 
  group_by(Cross) %>%
  summarise(correlation = round(cor(Length.off, Length.par), 3), r2 = round(cor(Length.off, Length.par)^2, 3)))
(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length2 <- parents_paired_length() %>% 
  group_by(sex.dam, sex.off) %>%
  summarise(correlation = round(cor(Length.off, Length.par), 3), r2 = round(cor(Length.off, Length.par)^2, 3)))
(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length3 <- parents_paired_length() %>% 
  group_by(sex.sire, sex.off) %>%
  summarise(correlation = round(cor(Length.off, Length.par), 3), r2 = round(cor(Length.off, Length.par)^2, 3)))

gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1_NN <- as.data.frame(c(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1[4,2], gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1[4,3]*2))
gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1_NH <- as.data.frame(c(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1[3,2], gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1[3,3]*2))
gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1_HN <- as.data.frame(c(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1[2,2], gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1[2,3]*2))
gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1_HH <- as.data.frame(c(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1[1,2], gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1[1,3]*2))
gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length2_dF <- as.data.frame(c(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length2[1,3], gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length2[1,4]*2))
gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length2_dM <- as.data.frame(c(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length2[2,3], gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length2[2,4]*2))
gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length3_sF <- as.data.frame(c(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length3[1,3], gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length3[1,4]*2))

gilmour_r_and_h2_length_14_16 <- rbind(gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1_NN, gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1_NH, gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1_HN, gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length1_HH, gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length2_dF, gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length2_dM, gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length3_sF, gilmour_parents_paired_14_16_length3_sM) %>% round(3)
```

### Slope

If we use the parents' phenotypic variance as a measure of VP, we can estimate h^2 by solving for:
trait_value_offspring = Cov_parent_offspring / Var_parent x trait_value_parent + c. The slope of the line (number under "estimate" for "Length.*" in the tibbles below) is mathematically equivalent to h^2.

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
# by cross
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_all_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.par, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16))
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_NN_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.par, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16 %>% filter(Cross == "NN")))
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_NH_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.par, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16 %>% filter(Cross == "NH")))
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_HN_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.par, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16 %>% filter(Cross == "HN")))
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_HH_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.par, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16 %>% filter(Cross == "HH")))

# by sex
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_dam_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.dam, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16))
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_sire_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.sire, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16))
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_dF_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.dam, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16 %>% filter(Sex.off == "F")))
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_dM_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.dam, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16 %>% filter(Sex.off == "M")))
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_sF_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.sire, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16 %>% filter(Sex.off == "F")))
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_sM_tbl <- tidy(lm(Length.off ~ Length.sire, data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16 %>% filter(Sex.off == "M")))

gilmour_slope_as_h2_length_14_16 <- as.data.frame(rbind(gilmour_h2_length_14_16_all_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_NN_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_NH_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_HN_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_HH_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_dam_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_sire_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_dF_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_dM_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_sF_tbl[2,2], gilmour_h2_length_14_16_sM_tbl[2,2]) %>% round(3))
colnames(gilmour_slope_as_h2_length_14_16) <- c("Heritability (h^2)")
gilmour_slope_as_h2_length_14_16$Category <- c("Overall", "NN", "NH", "HN", "HH", "Dam/All offspring", "Sire/All offspring", "Dam/Female offspring", "Dam/Male offspring", "Sire/Female offspring", "Sire/Male offspring")
(gilmour_slope_as_h2_length_14_16 <- gilmour_slope_as_h2_length_14_16[,c(2,1)])
```

### Animal model

Narrow-sense heritabilities (h^2) of were estimated from the proportion of the total phenotypic variance explained by the additive genetic variance component (h^2 = VA/VP) per Evans et al. (2019) [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10592-019-01174-4]. Maternal (M) versus paternal (S) effects were estimated as the proportion of total phenotypic variance explained by each parental variance component (M = VM/VP; S = VS/VP).

```{r}
gilmour_h2_length_14_16_dam_sire <- lmer(Length.off ~ (1|Length.sire)+(1|Length.dam), data = gilmour_triads_length_14_16, na.action = na.omit)
(summary(gilmour_h2_length_14_16_dam_sire))
plot(gilmour_h2_length_14_16_dam_sire)
```

### *Results*

```{r}
gilmour_r_and_h2_length_14_16 <- gilmour_r_and_h2_length_14_16[,c(1,3)]
```

### Slope

If we use the parents' phenotypic variance as a measure of VP, we can estimate h^2 by solving for:
trait_value_offspring = Cov_parent_offspring / Var_parent x trait_value_parent + c. The slope of the line is mathematically equivalent to h^2.

### Animal model

Narrow-sense heritabilities (h^2) of were estimated from the proportion of the total phenotypic variance explained by the additive genetic variance component (h^2 = VA/VP) per Evans et al. (2019) [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10592-019-01174-4]. Maternal (M) versus paternal (S) effects were estimated as the proportion of total phenotypic variance explained by each parental variance component (M = VM/VP; S = VS/VP).

Nothing to see here. I wouldn't bank on the HH result being real; it's probably an artifact of small sample size due to a lack of origin data for 2016.
